steps.title: Not Just a Wrapper
steps.narration: Here's what separates amateur AI work from professional: anyone can call the ChatGPT API. What makes a real AI integration is the architecture around it.

steps.title: Prompt Engineering
steps.narration: Your prompts are code too. They need to be documented, tested, and iterated. A well-crafted prompt with structured output format is the foundation of reliable AI integration.

steps.title: Output Validation
steps.narration: AI outputs are unpredictable. Professional integrations validate every response, handle malformed output gracefully, and never trust AI blindly.

steps.title: System Integration
steps.narration: AI becomes powerful when it connects to real systems‚ÄîGitHub for code review, databases for context, APIs for action. This is where the magic happens.

steps.title: Production Ready
steps.narration: Caching, rate limiting, cost tracking, graceful degradation. These concerns separate demos from real products. Your capstone must address all of them.

steps.title: Bad Prompts Fail
steps.narration: Review this code and find bugs. That's a bad prompt. It's vague, has no context, and produces inconsistent output you can't parse programmatically.

steps.title: Set a Role
steps.narration: Start with: You are a senior Python developer performing a code review. This gives the AI context and expertise to draw from. Roles dramatically improve output quality.

steps.title: Be Specific
steps.narration: List exactly what you want. Analyze for: security vulnerabilities, performance issues, style violations, missing error handling. Specificity gets specific results.

steps.title: Structure Output
steps.narration: Request JSON with a defined schema. Severity, type, line number, description, suggestion. Now you can parse the output reliably in your code.

steps.title: Test & Iterate
steps.narration: Version your prompts like code. Track what works and what doesn't. The best prompts evolve through iteration, not guesswork.

steps.title: Six Weeks Ago
steps.narration: Six weeks ago, you had a degree and some code. You could write programs but hadn't built systems. The gap between academia and industry felt vast.

steps.title: What You've Built
steps.narration: Production data layer. Event-driven pipeline. API integration suite. System design portfolio. A deployed full-stack app. And now, an AI-augmented tool.

steps.title: Interview Ready
steps.narration: The interview question isn't scary‚Äîyou've designed systems bigger than what they'll ask. The job posting requirements aren't intimidating‚Äîyou've built things that exceed them.

steps.title: The Gap Is Closed
steps.narration: You're not just a CS student anymore. You're an engineer. They taught you to code. We taught you to build. Now go show them what you can do.

questions.question: What separates a professional AI integration from 'just a ChatGPT wrapper'?
options: Prompt engineering, validation, system integration, and production concerns
questions.explanation: Professional AI integration requires thoughtful prompt engineering, robust output validation, meaningful system integration, and production concerns like caching and rate limiting.

questions.question: Why is output validation critical in AI integrations?
options: AI outputs are unpredictable and can be malformed or incorrect
It's required by OpenAI's terms of service
questions.explanation: AI outputs are inherently unpredictable. Professional integrations validate every response, handle malformed output gracefully, and never blindly trust AI-generated content.

questions.question: Which production concern is NOT mentioned as essential for AI integration?
options: Graceful degradation when AI is unavailable
questions.explanation: Essential production concerns include caching, rate limiting, cost tracking, and graceful degradation. The specific model version is less important than how you handle the integration.

questions.question: What's the first step in crafting a good prompt?
options: Setting a role for the AI
Making it as short as possible
questions.explanation: Setting a role (e.g., 'You are a senior Python developer') gives the AI context and expertise to draw from. This dramatically improves output quality and consistency.

questions.question: Why should you request structured JSON output from AI?
options: So you can reliably parse the output in your code
questions.explanation: Structured JSON output with a defined schema (severity, type, line number, etc.) can be reliably parsed by your application, enabling automated processing of AI responses.

questions.question: How should you treat your prompts over time?
options: Write once and never change them
Version them like code, track what works, iterate
Keep them as short as possible
questions.explanation: Prompts are code! They should be versioned, documented, tested, and iterated. The best prompts evolve through systematic improvement, not guesswork.

questions.question: What have you built across this entire course?
options: Data layer, event pipeline, API integration, system design portfolio, full-stack app, and AI-augmented tool
questions.explanation: Across six chapters, you've built a production data layer, event-driven pipeline, API integration suite, system design portfolio, deployed full-stack app, and AI-augmented tool.

questions.question: What's the key difference between coding and building?
options: Coding is just programs; building is designing systems with production concerns
questions.explanation: Coding produces programs. Building produces systems‚Äîwith architecture, production concerns, testing, deployment, and real-world integration. This course bridged that gap.

questions.question: After completing this course, what should you be able to confidently say in interviews?
options: I can solve any LeetCode problem
I've built production systems that exceed typical job requirements
questions.explanation: Your portfolio now demonstrates real system design and implementation. You've built things that exceed typical job requirements‚Äîthe best interview answer is 'let me show you.'
